On Thu, Jul 03, 2003 at 11:56:23PM -0400, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> With all due respect, the signing/court issue is a
> red-herring.

Well, it was in response to part of Paul's message, and seems quite
relevant.  It's perhaps only partially relevant to what you ask here
though.

> In real life, I have a http://universalcard.com
> credit card.  When I log in (via a web form), I
> arrive at the homepage for my account:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary
> 
> This page has my current balance, available
> credit, last payment made, and last payment date,
> among other information.  There is also a link on
> that page to:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> I can also link to a printable version of my
> unbilled transactions:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/UnbilledTrans?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> Both printable versions are simply current records
> of my account state without any links/buttons to
> make changes.
> 
> I'd like to be able to provide third parties
> (e.g. my accountant) with access to these pages,
> but I can't without providing them with control
> over my entire account.
> 
> The questions are:
> 1. Is this system RESTful?

Good question.  REST has an interface constraint called "identification
of resources", and there is clearly a resource in your example which is
not being identified ("The summary of Alex's account").  Roy's
dissertation is a bit vague with respect to what this constraint
actually constrains, so it's hard for me to say with any certainty.

But my hunch is that it is still RESTful, but with an obvious bug that
an important resource isn't identified.  It would be unRESTful if,
for example, cookies were used to define the context for interpretation
of that indirect reference (whether that was authentication info, or
anything else).

> 2. Would it be RESTful if it used HTTP-auth rather than cookie auth?

If it used cookie auth, it wouldn't be RESTful.

MB
